data.title: Stock Picks: AMMB And Orkim
data.description:
RHB Investment Bank Bhd (RHB Research) has identified AMMB Holdings Bhd and Orkim Bhd as stocks displaying bullish technical momentum, following recent breakouts on strong trading volumes.

AMMB Holdings may see its upward trajectory extended after breaching the RM6.60 resistance level with high volume, validating a bullish continuation pattern.

RHB Research said sustaining prices above this breakout point could pave the way towards the next resistance at RM6.90, followed by RM7.15. However, a decline below the RM6.35 support level would invalidate the bullish setup and signal a potential pullback.

Meanwhile, Orkim has extended its rally with a decisive breakout above its resistance level, supported by elevated trading activity.

The stock’s close above RM1.06 confirms that bullish momentum remains intact, positioning it to test the next resistance at RM1.12 and subsequently RM1.17, according to the research house. On the downside, a move below the RM1.01 support level would negate the positive outlook and could trigger a correction.

RHB Research’s technical view suggests both counters are trading within favourable momentum trends, although key support levels will need to hold to sustain the bullish bias.

data.title: Wall Street Slides As Nvidia Fails To Spark AI Rally
data.description:
US stocks fell sharply on Thursday as a post-earnings sell-off in Nvidia weighed heavily on technology counters, dragging the Nasdaq lower and putting pressure on the broader market.

The Nasdaq Composite dropped 273.69 points, or 1.18%, to 22,878.38, while the S&P 500 shed 37.27 points, or 0.54%, to 6,908.86.

In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 17.05 points, or 0.03%, to 49,499.20, supported by strength in cyclical sectors.

Nvidia shares slid 5.5% despite posting fourth-quarter results that exceeded analysts’ expectations and issuing guidance above market estimates. Investors appeared unsettled by slowing revenue growth and increasingly challenging year-on-year comparisons.

The Philadelphia SE Semiconductor index dropped 3.2%, leaving it close to ending what would have been a record 11-week winning streak.

“It feels like an Nvidia hangover that’s specific to the AI space,” said Michael Green, chief strategist at Simplify Asset Management in Philadelphia.

He added, “The S&P itself is being dragged down by Nvidia and the Magnificent 7, and the Nasdaq is really getting hammered.”

“It’s as simple as investors being levered long in Nvidia and short the AI disruption,” Green added.

He concluded, “And when that failed to materialize in a large enough scale, they sold out of their position, driving Nvidia down and pushing the stocks they were short back up.”

Among the S&P 500’s 11 major sectors, technology and communication services posted the steepest losses, while financials rose 1.3%, lifted by gains in major banks. The software and services index climbed 1.4%, even as AI-linked volatility persisted.

Trading volume on US exchanges totalled 19.55 billion shares, below the 20-day average of 20.31 billion.

data.title: Decliners Dominate Bursa As Dutch Lady, Maybank And TM Lead Losses
data.description:
The stock market closed with broad-based weakness on Feb 26 as decliners outnumbered gainers 746 to 367, signalling cautious sentiment in the market.

Meanwhile, some 520 counters were unchanged, while 1,136 counters were untraded and 165 suspended.

Leading the losses, Dutch Lady Milk Industries Bhd slid 88 sen to RM32.20, followed by Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), down 36 sen to RM12. Telecom giant Telekom Malaysia Bhd (TM) eased 29 sen to RM7.46, while Amway (M) Holdings Bhd and Hong Leong Bank Bhd fell 26 sen and 20 sen to RM5.11 and RM23.84 respectively.

On the upside, Sunway Construction Group Bhd led gainers, adding 35 sen to RM7.25, followed by Petronas Dagangan Bhd up 32 sen to RM22.28 and Nestlé (M) Berhad rising 30 sen to RM110.80.

The market reflected cautious trading as investors weighed corporate results and broader economic signals, keeping overall activity selective and focused on blue-chip movers.

data.title: Cautious Consumer Sentiment Bites At Padini
data.description:
MBSB Investment Bank Bhd (MBSB Research) and CIMB Investment Bank Bhd (CIMB Securities) both maintain their BUY calls on Padini Holdings Bhd, citing expectations of normalising earnings and stronger second-half performance despite softer first-half results.

MBSB Research kept its target price at RM2.22, while CIMB Securities lowered its target price slightly to RM2.25, reflecting weaker sales volumes in 1HFY26.

Padini reported 2QFY26 revenue of RM484.0 million, up 20.7% sequentially but down 7.9% year-on-year, driven by festive season demand that lifted footfall and consumer spending.

Core profit attributable to the parent (PATANCI) rose 109.7% quarter-on-quarter to RM47.1 million, supported by higher festive-driven sales, but declined 21.1% year-on-year due to elevated operating costs including rental-related service tax and higher depreciation charges.

For the first half of FY26, core PATANCI fell 14.4% to RM69.6 million, with margins contracting to 7.9%, underscoring persistent cost pressures despite relatively stable revenue. A third interim dividend of 1.8 sen per share was declared during the quarter, bringing total 1HFY26 DPS to 3.6 sen.

Analysts noted that weaker sales volumes reflected cautious consumer sentiment amid a softer macroeconomic backdrop and elevated global trade uncertainties.

Sequentially, 2QFY26 revenue and profits benefited from festive and school holiday demand, as well as an earlier Chinese New Year in 2026.

Gross margin improved to 39.8% year-on-year, supported by a more profitable product mix, reduced discounting, and MYR strength against the RMB.

Looking ahead, Padini’s earnings are expected to recover in 2HFY26, underpinned by festive demand, ongoing warehouse automation, exposure to higher-margin product categories, and improved operating leverage once cost pressures stabilise.

Both research houses continue to view Padini favourably, highlighting its resilient mass-market positioning, solid balance sheet, net cash of RM818 million, and attractive dividend yields of 3.8–4.3% for FY26–28F.

As of 10.58 am, the stock price decreased 6.50% to RM1.87.

data.title: Bursa Ends Lower As Profit-Taking Weighs On Banks, KLCI Slips 0.39%
data.description:
Bursa Malaysia closed in the red on Feb 26, though the benchmark rebounded from its intraday low as profit-taking, particularly in financial heavyweights, capped gains.

The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI fell 6.87 points, or 0.39%, to 1,740.94 at 5pm, compared to the closing of 1,747.81 on Feb 25.

Banking stocks led the decline, with Malayan Banking Bhd sliding 36 sen to RM12, while CIMB Group Holdings Bhd edged down one sen to RM8.46. Public Bank Bhd bucked the trend, rising five sen to RM5. Tenaga Nasional Bhd was flat at RM14.18 and IHH Healthcare Bhd gained two sen to RM9.02.

Among active counters, Aquawalk Group Bhd dropped 7.5 sen to 28.5 sen, Zetrix AI Bhd eased half-a-sen to 80 sen, Nationgate Holdings Bhd slid 11.5 sen to 89.5 sen and Capital A Bhd slipped 1.5 sen to 59 sen, while Tanco Holdings Bhd held steady at RM1.53.

Broader market sentiment was negative, with the FBM Emas Index losing 55 points to 12,768.60, the FBMT 100 Index down 49.86 points to 12,594.31, and the FBM ACE Index retreating 37.40 points to 4,764.55.

data.title: Hong Kong Stocks Close Higher As Hang Seng Climbs Nearly 1%
data.description:
Hong Kong’s equity market ended Feb 27 on a buoyant note, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 0.95% to 26,630.54 points, signalling a modest rebound in risk appetite after recent volatility.

Market strength was broad-based: The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index rose 0.51% and the Hang Seng Tech Index gained 0.56% as investors rotated back into key segments.

Heavy turnover in marquee names underlined the day’s action. Fosun International was among the most active stocks, finishing up around 3.8% on strong volume, while some smaller-cap plays saw heightened speculative interest.

Not all movers were positive as certain small-cap issues suffered sharp declines, but overall sentiment lifted after recent weakness and ahead of fresh catalysts in Hong Kong’s IPO pipeline.

The market’s uptick capped a volatile week, with readings pointing to consolidation around current levels as investors digest macro signals and await direction from upcoming economic data and policy developments.

data.title: Singapore Stocks Finish Strong As STI Climbs 0.6%
data.description:
Singapore’s equity market wrapped up the trading week on a positive note on Feb 27, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.6% to 4,995.07, buoyed by broad-based gains amid mixed regional sentiment.

Market breadth was healthy, with 349 gainers outpacing 237 losers as two billion securities changed hands in a session that saw selective strength in heavyweight and mid-cap names.

Key movers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which led the blue-chip rally with a more than 10% jump, while Venture Corporation dragged on the index after sliding 7.5%.

Elsewhere on the Singapore Exchange, small-cap names saw notable activity: Aztech Global Ltd surged over 13% on heavy volume and Trek 2000 International Ltd climbed nearly 15%, underscoring pockets of speculative interest.

Despite the upbeat close, broader regional cues were mixed, with technology and cyclical stocks showing uneven performance in Asia amid lingering global uncertainties.

Singapore’s strong finish trimmed weekly losses and capped a volatile session as investors head into month-end.

data.title: Bitcoin, Ethereum Rebound As Derivatives Expiry Tests Market Nerves
data.description:
Crypto markets found their footing on Feb 27, with Bitcoin and Ethereum staging a sharp rebound ahead of a major options expiry event.

Bitcoin climbed back toward the US$67,000-US$68,000 range, gaining roughly 4%-5% in 24 hours and briefly approaching the US$70,000 level. The move was fuelled by renewed ETF inflows and short-covering activity, signalling institutional buyers are stepping back into the market after recent volatility.

Ethereum outperformed on a percentage basis, rising more than 8% earlier in the week and reclaiming ground above US$2,000 before moderating. The rally in Ethereum and broader altcoins suggests risk appetite is returning, though conviction remains fragile.

The immediate catalyst: Billions of dollars in Bitcoin and Ethereum options contracts set to expire. Large derivatives settlements often compress price ranges or trigger sharp swings as traders rebalance positions. With “max pain” levels clustered below current spot prices, volatility risk remains elevated.

For now, the market narrative is one of cautious stabilisation. A sustained move above US$70,000 for Bitcoin or US$2,100 for Ethereum would signal renewed bullish momentum. Failure to hold recent gains, however, could reopen downside pressure.

data.title: Bitcoin Slide Below US$64,000 After Iran Strike
data.description:
Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies fell sharply after the US and Israel began striking targets across Iran on Saturday, causing ripples across high-risk assets.

Bitcoin dropped as much as 3.8% to $63,038, before stablising to trade around the $64,000 mark as of 6 a.m. in New York. Ether, the second-largest token, slid as much as 4.5% to $1,836. Roughly $128 billion in market value was erased across digital assets in the immediate aftermath of the news, according to data from CoinGecko.

For Bitcoin, the weekend losses extend a months-long selloff in crypto markets, beginning with the liquidation of some $19 billion in leveraged positions in October. Bitcoin has fallen around 50% from its all-time peak of over $126,000 earlier that month, unable to latch on to rallies in gold and other safe-haven assets.

data.title: Wall Street Ends Lower As AI Valuation Worries Mount
data.description:
Wall Street closed in the red on Feb 27 as investors grappled with lofty technology valuations and lingering uncertainty over the broader impact of artificial intelligence (AI).

Reuters reported that the benchmark S&P 500 fell 0.43%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.05% and the Nasdaq Composite slid 0.92%, as semiconductor stocks retreated from recent highs.

Shares of Nvidia, the world’s most valuable company and a bellwether for the AI trade, fell 3.5%, extending losses from the prior session despite posting better-than-expected earnings. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index declined 1.2%.

Globally, the MSCI All Country World Index slipped 0.25% on the day but still posted a weekly gain of 0.35%, while Europe’s STOXX 600 edged up 0.11%.

US Treasury yields fell as investors sought safety, with the 10-year yield down 6.3 basis points (bps) to 3.96%, and the two-year yield also falling 6.3bps to 3.385%. Germany’s 10-year Bund yield slipped 1bps to 2.644%.

In currency markets, sterling eased 0.07% to US$1.3447 after Britain’s Labour Party suffered an election setback in Greater Manchester. The dollar index was little changed, down 0.06% at 97.67, while the euro rose 0.14% to US$1.1813. The yen pared earlier gains to trade at 156.18 per dollar following softer Japanese inflation and factory output data.

Safe-haven demand lifted precious metals, with spot gold climbing 1.5% to US$5,263.59 an ounce and silver surging 6.1% to US$93.74.

Investors now turn their focus to further developments in AI-driven earnings momentum and geopolitical negotiations, both of which are likely to steer market sentiment in the weeks ahead.

data.title: Despite 4Q Decline Syarikat Takaful Remains Favourable
data.description:
MBSB Investment Bank Bhd (MBSB Research) and Hong Leong Investment Bank Bhd (HLIB) have maintained BUY calls on Syarikat Takaful Malaysia Keluarga Bhd (STMB), with revised target prices of RM3.95 and RM4.09 respectively, highlighting solid fundamentals, robust capital, and attractive dividend yields as key positives.

The research house noted that both family and general takaful segments delivered strong growth, while management’s outlook remains neutral yet constructive.

STMB reported FY25 core net profit of RM386 million, up 2% year-on-year, largely driven by higher takaful revenue which offset increased claims and tax charges.

Fourth-quarter core profit fell 20% quarter-on-quarter to RM92 million, impacted by the absence of the previous quarter’s investment windfall. Despite the quarterly decline, results were broadly in line with market expectations, accounting for around 102% of consensus full-year forecasts.

Gross written premiums (GWP) for the general takaful segment exceeded expectations, rising 14% year-on-year and outperforming the industry growth of 12.4%, supported by strong fire and motor results.

The family takaful segment continues to benefit from a diversified bancassurance network, limiting exposure to any single loan product and allowing margins to remain stable. Management also flagged that retakaful repricing in FY25 was moderate, aided by a relatively benign claims environment.

Looking ahead, STMB expects continued momentum, underpinned by sustained bank-led distribution, improving general takaful performance, and stable underwriting margins.

Analysts highlighted that the group’s strong capital position and progressive dividend policy, targeting around 40% payout, provide flexibility for strategic initiatives, including retail expansion and digital investments. FY26 core net profit forecasts have been revised upwards to RM389 million by MBSB, with dividend yield projected at 5.4%, while HLIB projects RM390.2 million and a 5.5% yield.

As of 3.31 pm, the stock price decreased 2.12% to RM3.23.

data.title: Farm Fresh Robust Earnings Marred By Australia’s 43% Slump
data.description:
CIMB Investment Bank Bhd (CIMB Securities) maintained its BUY call on Farm Fresh (FFB) with an unchanged target price of RM3.00, citing robust domestic demand, new product launches and regional expansion as key growth drivers.

CIMB Securities noted that FFB’s 3QFY3/26 core net profit (CNP) rose 17.3% year-on-year to RM31.6 million, lifting 9MFY3/26 CNP to RM101.4 million, in line with expectations at 70% of CIMB’s full-year forecast and 71% of Bloomberg consensus.

FY25 revenue for 9MFY3/26 grew 14.0% year-on-year, led by Malaysia with a 21.4% increase, supported by steady domestic demand, incremental contributions from new product launches, and stronger exports to Cambodia. These gains were partly offset by a 43.1% decline in Australia due to lower export deliveries.

EBITDA margin expanded 1.1 percentage points year-on-year to 21.1%, reflecting a favourable sales mix and lower input costs, consistent with the 21.5% growth in 9MFY26 CNP.

On a quarterly basis, 3QFY26 revenue fell 3.3% due to seasonal factors, including slower school milk deliveries during year-end holidays and weaker ice cream demand amid rainy periods, resulting in a 12.2% quarter-on-quarter dip in CNP.

Looking ahead, FFB’s domestic growth remains anchored by recent product launches, notably consumer-packaged ice cream, full-cream milk powder, and butter, supported by capacity expansion.

The Taiping plant upgrade now produces ~300,000 CPG ice cream units per day, while the commissioning of the Enstek plant has been delayed by six months to end-1QFY27F. Once operational, total group capacity is expected to reach ~1 million units per day, reinforcing volume momentum.

Regionally, FFB continues to expand across ASEAN, with Cambodia emerging as a bright spot as monthly exports have surpassed Singapore. A partner-led manufacturing facility in Cambodia is expected to commence operations in mid-2026.

CIMB Securities highlighted FFB’s leading position in Malaysia’s dairy industry, growing regional presence, diversified portfolio, and robust three-year EPS CAGR of 18.8% (FY25–28F).

As of 11.14 am, the stock price decreased 2.62% to RM2.60.

data.title: Weekly Recap: Kospi Soars Past 6,000 Before Profit-Taking Pullback
data.description:
South Korean equities ended the week of Feb 23–27 on a mixed note, with the benchmark KOSPI hitting fresh record highs before retreating on late profit-taking.

The KOSPI surged at the start of the week, climbing past the 6,000-point milestone on Feb 23, fueled by strong demand for semiconductor and technology stocks and positive global growth sentiment. Momentum extended to Feb 26, when the index briefly topped 6,300, reflecting enthusiasm over robust earnings prospects and artificial intelligence-led demand.

Tech heavyweights and large-cap counters led the advance, with semiconductors particularly buoyed by sustained institutional and foreign buying. Investor optimism underpinned broad participation across growth-oriented sectors, propelling the index to historic levels.

However, gains moderated late in the week as profit-taking intensified. On Feb 27, the KOSPI retreated about 1% to close at 6,244.13, snapping a six-day winning streak. Heavy foreign selling weighed on sentiment, while domestic retail and institutional investors helped cushion the decline.

Despite the pullback, overall market sentiment remained constructive. The index continued to trade near record highs, supported by underlying strength in technology stocks and selective buying across major sectors, highlighting resilience in South Korea’s equity market following its historic rally.

The week underscored the KOSPI’s bullish trajectory, even as short-term consolidation emerged after its landmark breakout.

data.title: STI Opens Lower As Nasdaq Decline Weighs On Sentiment
data.description:
Singapore shares opened slightly lower on Thursday, mirroring weakness in US technology stocks following a sharp post-earnings sell-off in Nvidia.

As at 9.10 am, the Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 5.92 points, or 0.12%, to 4,958.46, with decliners outnumbering advancers 124 to 102. Market turnover reached 188.27 million shares valued at S$314.75 million.

Yangzijiang Shipbuilding emerged as an early standout, climbing 8.93% to S$4.27, while other actively traded blue chips included DBS at S$57.01, UOB at S$36.52, Singtel at S$4.99, ST Engineering at S$9.75, City Developments at S$9.69 and Seatrium at S$2.34.

In derivatives trading, total volume reached 31,150 contracts. Nikkei 225 Index Futures for March were quoted at 58,300, while MSCI Singapore Index Futures for March stood at 456.85. The USD/SGD March futures were at 1.2624.

The muted local opening reflects lingering caution after U.S. markets fell, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 1.18% and the S&P 500 down 0.54%, while the Dow inched up 0.03%. Technology shares led losses, weighed by a 5.5% decline in Nvidia despite better-than-expected results, as investors digested slower revenue growth and challenging year-on-year comparisons.

Analysts noted the “Nvidia hangover” was dragging major indexes, with volatility in AI-linked stocks contributing to uneven trading sentiment globally.

data.title: Market Snapshot: Hang Seng Index Ends Higher After Choppy Week
data.description:
Trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange closed out a volatile week with the benchmark Hang Seng Index posting a modest overall gain, as early optimism gave way to bouts of profit-taking before a late rebound.

The week kicked off with strong upside momentum on Feb 23, with the index climbing more than 2% in early trade, supported by gains in technology and communications-related counters. Improved regional sentiment and renewed interest in growth sectors helped lift broader market confidence.

However, as the sessions progressed, volatility resurfaced. Investors trimmed positions in select heavyweight names amid mixed global cues and macro uncertainties, tempering earlier advances. Profit-taking in large-cap stocks weighed intermittently on the index, while sector performance turned uneven.

By Feb 27, the Hang Seng regained traction, rising 0.95% to close at 26,630.54, supported by strength in China-linked enterprises and selective buying in tech shares. Market turnover remained active throughout the week, reflecting sustained participation despite shifting sentiment.

Although fluctuations marked the trading period, the index managed to end the week slightly higher overall, signaling a cautiously constructive undertone even as investors navigated external risks.

Analysts view the near-term outlook as balanced, with attention focused on developments from mainland China and broader global markets that could shape directional momentum in the sessions ahead.

data.title: Bursa Opens Lower Amid Global Tech Sell-Off
data.description:
Bursa Malaysia opened lower on Thursday, tracking a broad sell-off in US technology stocks following a sharp post-earnings decline in Nvidia, which weighed on investor sentiment globally.

As at 9.11 am, the benchmark FBMKLCI fell 8.37 points, or 0.48%, to 1,732.57. Other key indices were also lower, with the FBM70 down 36.76 points (-0.21%) to 17,661.49, F4GBM slipping 4.29 points (-0.42%) to 1,024.72, FBMEMAS losing 56.73 points (-0.44%) to 12,711.87, and FBMSHA retreating 36.96 points (-0.30%) to 12,274.75.

Among the most active stocks, Velesto Energy led trading with 99.14 million shares, last done at RM0.305, while MBSB traded 98.35 million shares at RM0.710, down RM0.05. AMBEST changed hands at RM0.285, down RM0.025 on volume of 91.05 million shares.

Top gainers included Greatec rising RM0.15 to RM2.12 and MHC advancing RM0.15 to RM1.78. Meanwhile, MPI fell RM0.42 to RM31.72 and BKAWAN lost RM0.32 to RM19.38.

Market watchers noted that the weaker opening was in line with Wall Street, where the Nasdaq Composite fell 1.18% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.54% as Nvidia’s 5.5% drop and broader AI-related volatility dragged on tech counters.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, edged up 0.03%, supported by gains in cyclical sectors.

Trading on Bursa showed mixed momentum, with decliners slightly outnumbering advancers, reflecting caution among investors amid persistent volatility in technology-linked markets.

data.title: FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Slides 1.39% As Profit-Taking Hits Blue Chips
data.description:
FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI closed sharply lower on Feb 27, retreating 24.33 points or 1.39% to 1,716.61 as investors locked in gains following a recent rally.

Losses were broad-based across key indices. The FBM 70 fell 0.88% to 17,542.47, the FBM EMAS dropped 1.23% to 12,611.43, the FBM SHA declined 0.76% to 12,217.56, while the F4GBM slid 1.25% to 1,016.13.

Heavyweight banking counters led the retreat. Malayan Banking Bhd slipped four sen to RM11.96, Public Bank Bhd fell seven sen to RM4.93 and CIMB Group Holdings Bhd tumbled 42 sen to RM8.04.

However, selective buying emerged in defensive names. Tenaga Nasional Bhd rose 20 sen to RM14.38, while IHH Healthcare Bhd added 10 sen to RM9.12.

Trading interest remained robust, particularly among lower-priced and mid-cap stocks.

Electronics manufacturing services provider VS Industry Bhd was the most actively traded counter, easing two sen to 34.5 sen with over 125.9 million shares changing hands. Zetrix AI Bhd gained two sen to 82 sen on heavy volume, while property developer Tanco Holdings Bhd climbed six sen to RM1.59.

Construction-linked Malaysian Resources Corporation Bhd slipped half a sen to 31 sen.

The day’s pullback suggests investors are taking a breather after recent gains, with profit-taking concentrated in financial heavyweights even as selected defensives and speculative plays continued to see buying support.

data.title: Weekly Review: STI Ends Mixed As Volatility And Global Cues Drive Trading
data.description:
The benchmark Singapore Exchange closed the week of Feb 23–27 on an uneven note after a volatile stretch shaped by shifting global sentiment and earnings-driven movements.

The Straits Times Index (STI) began the week on firmer ground, tracking regional gains as improved risk appetite and currency stability lent early support to equities. Blue-chip counters provided initial momentum, keeping the index within sight of the 5,000 level.

However, sentiment turned cautious mid-week as weakness in U.S. technology stocks and mixed global cues prompted investors to pare positions. The STI opened lower on Feb 27, with decliners outnumbering gainers as broader risk appetite softened.

Despite the mid-week pullback, the index staged a recovery toward the latter part of the week, rising 0.6% in one session to close at 4,995.07, supported by selective buying in heavyweight and mid-cap names. Market breadth improved, reflecting renewed interest in pockets of the market even as overall sentiment remained measured.

For the week as a whole, the STI finished marginally softer, hovering just below the key 5,000 threshold after fluctuating through a series of mixed sessions.

Analysts expect near-term consolidation as investors balance corporate earnings developments with external macroeconomic signals, while monitoring global market volatility for clearer directional cues.

data.title: Nestle, PetGas Among Top Losers As Decliners Swamp Gainers
data.description:
Shares in Nestle (M) Bhd and Petronas Gas Bhd (PetGas) led the losers’ board as market breadth turned decisively negative, with 842 decliners overwhelming 376 gainers on Bursa Malaysia.

Nestle slipped 90 sen to RM109.90, topping the list of decliners, while PetGas fell 48 sen to RM17.96. Financial heavyweights also came under pressure, with Hong Leong Financial Group Bhd shedding 60 sen to RM21.30 and Hong Leong Bank Bhd down 56 sen to RM23.28. Plantation counter United Plantations Bhd eased 48 sen to RM29.52.

On the upside, Fraser & Neave Holdings Bhd emerged as the top gainer, climbing RM1.44 to RM34.94. UWC Bhd advanced 39 sen to RM4.50, while Hume Cement Industries Bhd rose 36 sen to RM3.88. Also among the gainers were Hong Leong Industries Bhd, up 34 sen to RM18.72, and Kelington Group Bhd, which added 26 sen to RM5.47 on robust trading volume.

Overall, 491 counters were unchanged, while 981 were untraded and 76 suspended, reflecting cautious sentiment across the broader market.

Despite the negative breadth, trading activity strengthened. Turnover rose to 3.53 billion units valued at RM5.53 billion compared to 2.98 billion units worth RM4.07 billion in the previous session, indicating active portfolio rebalancing.

The session’s divergence — selective buying amid broad-based selling — underscores lingering caution as investors trim positions in selected blue chips while rotating into pockets of resilience.

data.title: Bursa Slips On Profit-Taking Pressure As Volatility Picks Up
data.description:
Bursa Malaysia ended the trading week on a weaker footing after a volatile stretch marked by profit-taking and cautious sentiment, mirroring softer regional cues.

The benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI (FBM KLCI) began the week on a steadier note, supported by improved regional sentiment and currency stability. However, gains proved short-lived as investors moved to lock in profits following earlier advances in February.

By mid-week, selling pressure became more evident, particularly in banking and selected heavyweight counters. On Feb 26, the FBM KLCI slipped 0.39% to close at 1,740.94, as decliners outpaced gainers across the broader market.

The downturn intensified toward the week’s close. On Feb 27, the benchmark fell 1.39% — its sharpest drop in recent weeks — dragged down by sustained profit-taking in blue-chip stocks. Market breadth remained negative, reflecting a cautious stance among both institutional and retail participants.

Trading activity was measured, with investors adopting a selective approach amid ongoing corporate earnings releases and mixed global economic signals. Broader indices also tracked lower, highlighting the market’s consolidative tone.

Market Outlook: Analysts expect the local bourse to trade within a defined range in the near term as investors digest earnings results and monitor external developments. While downside risks persist, bargain-hunting interest may emerge should valuations turn more compelling.
